prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not keeping my husband undisturbed while he works from home.
My husband switched jobs within the past year or so and new job allows him to work from home  a few days a week.  He decided to set up his office in our bedroom.  I suggested he set up in the basement where he would be guaranteed silence and very little disruption.  He prefers to work from our bedroom because the view is better.  His job is 90% conference calls so while he is up there, I have to keep kids from disturbing him which basically means the whole top floor of our house is off limits while he is on calls.  It also means I can’t shower in my bathroom, do chores, put away laundry, or even take a nap when the baby is sleeping.  I also work from home but also take on most of the house chores and dealing with kids.  Him being up there negates my ability to take a damn shower or a poop in peace when I want to.   Since we have adequate space in the basement I told him that we would never bother him while he is down there ever but I can’t promise him silence if he stays in our bedroom. He says i am the asshole for not being quiet when he’s on calls while I think he is the asshole for not setting his office up in the dang basement. Please resolve our fight for us.  Thank you!
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, so the user is asking whether the author is in the wrong in this situation. Let's break it down. The husband set up his office in the bedroom despite the wife suggesting the basement. His job is mostly conference calls, so he needs quiet. The problem is that the wife can't do her chores or even have quiet time when he's working there. She works from home too and handles most housework and kids. The husband says she's the asshole for not keeping quiet, but she thinks he's the asshole for not moving to the basement.

Hmm, where do I start? First, the husband chose the bedroom over the basement. The wife offered an alternative that would be better for his work (basement for silence), but he prioritized the view. That's a key point. If he didn't want disruptions, maybe the basement was the logical choice. But he picked the bedroom, which is a shared space. So the question is, should the wife have to accommodate his preference when it's creating a problem for her?

She's working from home and managing the house and kids. When he's in the bedroom on calls, she can't do her own work or take care of basic needs like a shower or bathroom break. It seems like an imbalance here. The husband is using a space that's typically for both of them, and his choice is limiting her ability to function. The wife is trying to be considerate by saying they won't disturb him in the basement, but he's not willing to take that option. 

So, the author (the wife) is not in the wrong. The husband made a choice that affects her daily life. The wife is justified in pointing out that his choice is causing issues. The husband is the one who might be in the wrong because he's not considering her needs and the practicality of the space. The wife can't be expected to give up her own time and space in a bedroom they share. It's more about mutual respect and shared responsibility. The answer should be B.
